body:
I've noticed this discrepancy before, but am still not quite sure what to make of it.  Consider this spack output:

```
=> Warning: The contents of /g/g12/scogland/spack/var/spack/stage/judy-1.0.5-yglmhlllrlexvgi5f6pl267qagasjt3g/Judy-1.0.5.tar.gz look like HTML.
  The checksum will likely be bad.  If it is, you can use
  'spack clean --dist' to remove the bad archive, then fix
  your internet gateway issue and install again.
==> Error: md5 checksum failed for /g/g12/scogland/spack/var/spack/stage/judy-1.0.5-yglmhlllrlexvgi5f6pl267qagasjt3g/Judy-1.0.5.tar.gz.
Expected 115a0d26302676e962ae2f70ec484a54 but got d99fae1fc48fd56a9469a69176abbaa7.

shell returned 1

Press ENTER or type command to continue
usage: spack [-h] [-d] [-k] [-m] [-p] [-v] [-V] SUBCOMMAND ...
spack: error: unrecognized arguments: --dist
```

The download/check failure message directs users to use the `spack clean --dist` command to clean up the dead file, but that command appears to not work/exist.  Is there an alternative that should be swapped in?
title: spack clean --dist?
